newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico plans satellite sale next month - gov't.
newsitem.headline: Mexico plans satellite sale next month - gov't.

text.p: The Mexican government plans by next month to begin selling stakes in the nation's fixed satellites through a public stock offering, the Communication and Transport Ministry's privatization coordinator Jorge Silberstein said on Monday.
"We will create a company to sell shares and should start by May," Silberstein said in an interview.

Mexico's fixed satellites are Morelos II and Solidaridad I and II. Morelos II will need replacing by 1998, with a contract for the new satellite awarded to Hughes Communications International Inc., a division of Hughes Electronics Corp.
The government will retain oversight over satellite communications, their orbital slots and their orbital frequencies.
In what Silberstein called a "trade sale" scheme, the government will sell a larger stake, then place the remaining participation on the Mexican Stock Market (Bolsa).
Up for sale is the use of the three satellites currently in orbit, plus space for fixed satellites, related ground infrastructure and any future satellites.
